COBIE.instructions: Use the arrow keys to move. Get to the right side of the screen to progress to the next level! Press Z to go into the level editor
COBIE.description: A simple, yet difficult tile-based platformer game with a level editor.
COBIE.notes: This game is hard. I haven't finished it yet. The goal was to create a template game for a tile-based platformer.
COBIE.credits: Code by me. Art by me. Music from Nintendo. SFX from me and Nintendo.

Robot Survival Game.instructions: Defeat the robots attacking you to get more money. Use the money to buy blocks and weapons. Try to survive all the robots! W: move up, S: move down, A: move left, D: move right, Q: open block menu, E: open weapon menu, space: place block, mouse: aim and attack with weapon, or select option
Robot Survival Game.description: A wave-based survival game; parts skill and strategy. Fight close-range enemies with melee weapons and ranged enemies with ranged weapons.
Robot Survival Game.notes: My most finished game to date. I had a lot of fun making this, particularly with the wide range of weapons. Try to save enough money to get the lightsaber!
Robot Survival Game.credits: Code by me. Art by me. SFX by me.

Triangle Boss Game.instructions: Defeat the triangle by shooting the core. Arrow keys to move and jump. Mouse to aim and shoot.
Triangle Boss Game.description: A platformer boss based off a cool idea I had. In most cases, you would have to destroy the body triangles before you get to attack the core.
Triangle Boss Game.notes: I am very happy with the end result. The effects make the experience all the more exciting.
Triangle Boss Game.credits: Code by me. Art by me. SFX by me. Music by me.

Swimming Up the Food Chain.instructions: Eat anything edible and smaller than you to get larger. Avoid anything nonedible or larger than you. Left arrow to rotate counter-clockwise. Right arrow to rotate clockwise. Up arrow to accelerate. Space to eat.
Swimming Up the Food Chain.description: This is my most finished game. It is both satistying and terrifying. It is easy to progess through the first levels, but each level is harder than the last.
Swimming Up the Food Chain.notes: This game was made with the challenge to only use assets from the Scratch Library.
Swimming Up the Food Chain.credits: Code by me, Art and SFX from the Scratch Library.

Polar Spinning Nodes.instructions: watch and enjoy the satisfying patterns.
Polar Spinning Nodes.description: Each image has a number of nodes. These nodes adjust their distance from the center of the image according to their specific angle. A straight line is drawn from each node to the next. Because of the limited number of nodes, they create beautiful patterns based off whatever equation is put.
Polar Spinning Nodes.notes: I skimmed through my Calculus I textbook before the class started. In it, I discovered polar shapes. Later, I came across a cylindrical bowl with one of those polar shapes in the middle, formed by the reflection of the light across the round inside of the bowl. Fascinated, I decided to create a simulation based off polar coordinates. I am very happy with the result.

Big Polar Spinning Nodes.instructions: watch and enjoy the satisfying patterns. Press Space to change the pattern.
Big Polar Spinning Nodes.description: Each image has a number of nodes. These nodes adjust their distance from the center of the image according to their specific angle. A straight line is drawn from each node to the next. Because of the limited number of nodes, they create beautiful patterns based off whatever equation is put.
Big Polar Spinning Nodes.notes: I skimmed through my Calculus I textbook before the class started. In it, I discovered polar shapes. Later, I came across a cylindrical bowl with one of those polar shapes in the middle, formed by the reflection of the light across the round inside of the bowl. Fascinated, I decided to create a simulation based off polar coordinates. I am very happy with the result.

Tree Fractals.instructions: Watch and enjoy. Slide the sliders to create different patterns.
Tree Fractals.description: This simulation makes fractals based off a specific number of branches, iterations, and angle. They usually end up looking like trees.
Tree Fractals.notes: I have always enjoyed fractals and had wanted to create a simulation for a long time. One thing to note is that sometimes the simulation will not draw anything sometimes when it should. This is because as the number of iterations or branches increases, the time it takes to draw the simulation increases much faster; it has an exponential time complexity. If I took out the code that stopped the drawing, it would crash the browser.

Math Color Patterns.instructions: Watch and enjoy. Slide the sliders to look at different patterns or change the resolution.
Math Color Patterns.description: The image is made of little squares. Each square follows the same set of rules. The rules determine what color the pixel should be based off its position, the time, or the mouse position.
Math Color Patterns.notes: It was fun using different math equations and seeing how they would translate to the screen.

Spinning Circular Patterns.instructions: Watch and enjoy. Press space to change the way it looks.
Spinning Circular Patterns.description: Each node revolves around the center. The speed at which this happens is relative to the distance from the center.
Spinning Circular Patterns.notes: Try to watch for a few minutes to see the simulation come full circle.

Dynamic Polygons.description: This animation has moving polygons that resize. It is relaxing to watch.
Dynamic Polygons.notes: This is more of an animation, but since it is heavily based off math, I categorized it as a simulation.

Fighting Circles.description: The circles go for their nearest enemy and attack.
Fighting Circles.notes: There is a 0.1% chance of a circle mutating into a giant circle.

BOIDS (Bird-oid Objects).instructions: Watch and enjoy. Use the arrow keys and space to control the predator and try to catch a boid. Press Z to show or hide controls. Slide the sliders to change the way the boids behave.
BOIDS (Bird-oid Objects).description: These boids are based after the behavior of real-life creatures such as a flock of birds or a school of fish.
BOIDS (Bird-oid Objects).notes: It was really fun (albeit hard) to make this work, as simulations based off real phenomena are me favorite types of simulations.

Pathfinding Arrows.instructions: Watch and enjoy. click to make a blank space.
Pathfinding Arrows.description: To summarize, the blue square sends out directions for the orange ones to follow.
Pathfinding Arrows.notes: Understanding how the algorithm worked was harder than the coding part.

Pixel Color Patterns.instructions: Watch and enjoy. Slide the slider to change the pattern.
Pixel Color Patterns.description: The color and brightness of the pixels are based after their x and y positions and a time variable. Different math equations determine the different patterns.
Pixel Color Patterns.notes: There are infinite possibilities for this one. I chose some of my favorites.

Inertia Force Balls.instructions: Watch and enjoy. Press B to create a ball at the mouse. Press keys 1-6 to change the brush, and click to draw.
Inertia Force Balls.description: A simple, but satisfying simulation of balls that act under forces and inertia.
Inertia Force Balls.notes: Though it took an extremely short time to make, it still is fun to play around with.

Culminating Fight.description: A looping orchestral rock song that could be used as a song for a final boss in a video game. It almost uses a full orchestra, and has some traditional Chinese and Japanese instruments.
Culminating Fight.notes: This was the first song I made that I was fully satisfied with.

Spectre Spectacle.description: A looping song made that doesn't necessarily fit any genre, but I am very fond of it. The melody and instrument choices, particularly the toy piano and pipe organs, make it sound like a ghost theme. The drums add an interesting layer.
Spectre Spectacle.notes: This is my first song that changes time signatures. I like the way it transitions back from 3/4 to 4/4.
Spectre Spectacle.credits: Song by me. Some inspiration from Nintendo.

Shop Theme.description: A looping song that I can only describe as waiting music. It can be used for a shop, an elevator, a waiting room, etc.
Shop Theme.notes: This is the first song that I wrote on guitar first.
Shop Theme.credits: Music by me. Inspiration from Nintendo.

Wavering Woods.description: A short song that I think best represents a video game area, particularly a 'dark' forest.
Wavering Woods.notes: Listen with headphones for the full experience. I had to do some tricks to get the violin solo working, as Garageband offers no violin solo instrument. Unfinished, so it ends somewhat abruptly.

Dusk Above the Clouds.description: A song that gives me the feeling of flying above the clouds during dusk on a cloudy day.
Dusk Above the Clouds.notes: Listen with headphones for the full experience. Unfinished, so it ends somewhat abruptly.

Vello City.description: A looping song that sounds like a race through a futuristic city.
Vello City.notes: I experimented a lot with different effects for this one. I think it came out well.

Evanescent.description: An interesting song that doesn't fit any genre. The chiptune lead makes it really unique.
Evanescent.notes: The chiptune solo remains one of the best I have ever written. I also think the song ends pretty well.
Evanescent.credits: Composed by me and Evan Kuo. Produced by me.

RPG Battle Theme.description: A video game retro-sounding song that sounds like battle theme from an RPG game.
RPG Battle Theme.notes: This is the most refined chiptune song I have made.

The Cloud-Piercing Pillar.description: A video game retro-sounding song that sounds to me like you are climbing a tower that reaches into the sky.
The Cloud-Piercing Pillar.notes: The intro is among the best I have ever made. Listen to the rise and fall of the secondary melody (in the intro) and think about how it makes you feel. Unfinished, so it ends somewhat abruptly.

Lumino City.description: A song that sounds like you walked into a bright, beautiful, bustling city for the first time.
Lumino City.notes: The instrument selection in this one fits the song really well. Unfinished, so it ends somewhat abruptly.
